  • dyad.stats.eccentricity.powerlaw

dyad.stats.eccentricity.powerlaw#

dyad.stats.eccentricity.powerlaw = <scipy.stats._continuous_distns.powerlaw_gen object>#

A power-function continuous random variable.

As an instance of the rv_continuous class, powerlaw object inherits from it a collection of generic methods (see below for the full list), and completes them with details specific for this particular distribution.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.rvs(a, loc=0, scale=1, size=1, random_state=None)#

Random variates.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.pdf(x, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Probability density function.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.logpdf(x, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Log of the probability density function.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.cdf(x, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Cumulative distribution function.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.logcdf(x, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Log of the cumulative distribution function.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.sf(x, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Survival function (also defined as 1 - cdf, but sf is sometimes more accurate).

dyad.stats.eccentricity.logsf(x, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Log of the survival function.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.ppf(q, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Percent point function (inverse of cdf — percentiles).

dyad.stats.eccentricity.isf(q, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Inverse survival function (inverse of sf).

dyad.stats.eccentricity.moment(order, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Non-central moment of the specified order.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.stats(a, loc=0, scale=1, moments='mv')#

Mean(‘m’), variance(‘v’), skew(‘s’), and/or kurtosis(‘k’).

dyad.stats.eccentricity.entropy(a, loc=0, scale=1)#

(Differential) entropy of the RV.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.fit(data)#

Parameter estimates for generic data. See scipy.stats.rv_continuous.fit for detailed documentation of the keyword arguments.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.expect(func, args=(a, ), loc=0, scale=1, lb=None, ub=None, conditional=False, \*\*kwds)#

Expected value of a function (of one argument) with respect to the distribution.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.median(a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Median of the distribution.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.mean(a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Mean of the distribution.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.var(a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Variance of the distribution.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.std(a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Standard deviation of the distribution.

dyad.stats.eccentricity.interval(confidence, a, loc=0, scale=1)#

Confidence interval with equal areas around the median.

See also

pareto

Notes

The probability density function for powerlaw is:

\[f(x, a) = a x^{a-1}\]

for \(0 \le x \le 1\), \(a > 0\).

powerlaw takes a as a shape parameter for \(a\).

The probability density above is defined in the “standardized” form. To shift and/or scale the distribution use the loc and scale parameters. Specifically, powerlaw.pdf(x, a, loc, scale) is identically equivalent to powerlaw.pdf(y, a) / scale with y = (x - loc) / scale. Note that shifting the location of a distribution does not make it a “noncentral” distribution; noncentral generalizations of some distributions are available in separate classes.

For example, the support of powerlaw can be adjusted from the default interval [0, 1] to the interval [c, c+d] by setting loc=c and scale=d. For a power-law distribution with infinite support, see pareto.

powerlaw is a special case of beta with b=1.

Examples

>>> import numpy as np
>>> from scipy.stats import powerlaw
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)

Calculate the first four moments:

>>> a = 0.659
>>> mean, var, skew, kurt = powerlaw.stats(a, moments='mvsk')

Display the probability density function (pdf):

>>> x = np.linspace(powerlaw.ppf(0.01, a),
...                 powerlaw.ppf(0.99, a), 100)
>>> ax.plot(x, powerlaw.pdf(x, a),
...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='powerlaw pdf')

Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a “frozen” RV object holding the given parameters fixed.

Freeze the distribution and display the frozen pdf:

>>> rv = powerlaw(a)
>>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf')

Check accuracy of cdf and ppf:

>>> vals = powerlaw.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], a)
>>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], powerlaw.cdf(vals, a))
True

Generate random numbers:

>>> r = powerlaw.rvs(a, size=1000)

And compare the histogram:

>>> ax.hist(r, density=True, bins='auto', histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2)
>>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]])
>>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False)
>>> plt.show()
